In Gallican regions the fast of the kalends of January was also observed. It is to this, possibly, that Philastrius‚ writing in the fourth century, refers when he speaks of the fast of the Epiphany? The aim of this observance in Gaul and Spain3 was to detach the faithful from the pagan masquerades and ceremonies of the 1st of January—ancient heathen customs‚ of which traces remain until the present day. It is possible, however, that this custom was adopted at the very beginning as a preparation for the observance of the Epiphany.4 From the example of the fast which precedes Easter, it was concluded that every high festival ought to have a preparatory fast immediately before it.
